Introduction

Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, most often caused by gallstone obstruction of the cystic duct (calculous cholecystitis), leading to bile stasis and inflammation, sometimes with secondary infection. A less common form, acalculous cholecystitis, occurs without stones and is typically seen in critically ill patients.

Pathophysiology



The most common cause of acute cholecystitis is obstruction by a gallstone within the cystic duct.  This results in obstructed bile flow through the duct and gallbladder distension.



The normal physiologic response to the ingestion of foods containing fat is the release of cholecystokinin (CCK), which triggers gallbladder contraction.  If the gallbladder contracts against a fixed obstruction (eg, due to a thick biliary sludge or gallstone), the rise in intragallbladder pressure can cause ischemia within the gallbladder wall (

figure 1
).  The ischemia triggers an inflammatory response in the gallbladder wall, resulting in neutrophilic infiltrate.  This inflammatory cascade is thought to be prostaglandin mediated.  Although the inflammation in the gallbladder wall starts without infection, secondary bacterial infection (typically with gut flora such as Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, or Enterococcus) often develops.



In cases of acalculous cholecystitis, bile stasis and ischemia of the gallbladder wall are precipitated by critical conditions such as recent major surgery, burns, or sepsis.  These conditions lead to poor blood flow to the gallbladder wall (often due to hypovolemia or hypotension), which causes necrosis and subsequent inflammation.

Risk factors

Acute calculous cholecystitis



  • Elevated cholesterol synthesis into bile, promoting supersaturation with cholesterol:  Hyperlipidemia, elevated estrogen (female sex, oral contraceptive pills, hormone replacement therapy), obesity, diabetes mellitus.
  • Gallbladder hypomotility, allowing bile stasis and stone precipitation:  Pregnancy, total parenteral nutrition (TPN) (due to lack of enteral stimulation), prolonged fasting, rapid weight loss, octreotide use.
  • Decreased bile acid synthesis (fibrate medications) or resorption in the ileum (Crohn disease).
  • Advancing age (>40), changing bile composition and gallbladder motility.
  • Hemolytic disorders, increasing bilirubin turnover and predisposing to pigmented gallstones:  Sickle cell disease, thalassemia.

Acalculous cholecystitis



  • Critical illness and systemic hypoperfusion, causing ischemic injury and impairing gallbladder motility:  Shock state, sepsis, severe burns.
  • Major surgery and trauma, especially abdominal or cardiothoracic procedures disrupting splanchnic circulation:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.
  • TPN.
  • Diabetes mellitus, resulting in neuropathy and impaired gallbladder emptying.
  • Immunosuppression, impairing defenses and contributing to exacerbated inflammation:  HIV/AIDS.

Pathology



The pathology of acute cholecystitis falls on a spectrum and depends mostly on the duration of the condition's course.  The inflammatory cascade triggered in acute cholecystitis can ultimately progress to ischemia and gangrene of the gallbladder wall.  Perforation and frank peritonitis can occur when there is loss of integrity in the gallbladder wall due to the friability of ischemic tissues.  The ischemic wall is then susceptible to secondary bacterial infection with gut flora.  Empyema of the gallbladder can also occur when the lumen of the gallbladder becomes filled with a mix of infected, purulent, and bilious material.



Chronic cholecystitis (a somewhat controversial term) refers to recurrent episodes of inflammation that lead to fibrosis and scarring of the gallbladder wall.  The course of chronic cholecystitis is more indolent because repeated episodes of inflammation (which can be in the presence or absence of a gallstone) cause dysfunction of gallbladder emptying, also called biliary dyskinesia.  The gallbladder is less effective in emptying due to scarring and has a reduced ejection fraction.

Clinical presentation



The hallmark of acute cholecystitis is RUQ abdominal pain, often associated with nausea, vomiting, and fever.  The pain may initially be colicky but becomes persistent as inflammation progresses.  Characteristic pain from acute cholecystitis radiates to the right shoulder blade.  On clinical examination, there may be a positive Murphy sign, which is indicated by halting of respiration with palpation of the RUQ (

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of acute cholecystitis relies on a combination of clinical presentation, laboratory evaluation, and imaging studies.

Laboratory evaluation



  • Complete blood count:  Leukocytosis with a left shift is typical, although it may be absent in early or mild cases.
  • Liver function tests:  There should be no elevation in bilirubin or alkaline phosphatase in uncomplicated acute calculous cholecystitis because the obstruction is typically within the cystic duct.  Transaminase levels may also be normal in uncomplicated cases.  If present, derangements in liver function testing should prompt investigation for complications.

Imaging studies



  • RUQ ultrasonography:  The first-line imaging modality when acute cholecystitis is suspected.  Imaging findings to support the diagnosis include:

    • Gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm).
    • Pericholecystic fluid.
    • Gallbladder distension.
    • Sonographic Murphy sign (tenderness when the ultrasonographic probe is pressed over the gallbladder).
    • Presence of gallstones or biliary sludge (
      figure 2
      ).
  • HIDA scan:  A nuclear medicine test using a radiotracer called "iminodiacetic acid" that is excreted into the biliary system.  HIDA is considered the gold standard when ultrasonographic findings are equivocal, which may be the case early in a patient's clinical course.  The absence of radiotracer migration (nonvisualization) to the gallbladder suggests cystic duct obstruction and cholecystitis.  Chronic cholecystitis can be identified on HIDA scan with delayed visualization of radiotracer in the gallbladder or reduced ejection fraction.
  • CT scan:  More comprehensive abdominal imaging used in complicated cases to assess for perforation, abscess formation, or alternate diagnoses such as pancreatitis.  CT scan is more sensitive than ultrasonography for detecting emphysematous cholecystitis, which would present with gas within the gallbladder wall.

Differential diagnosis



  • Symptomatic cholelithiasis (biliary colic):  Biliary colic presents with RUQ pain, which is episodic and resolves within hours, whereas the pain in acute cholecystitis is more persistent.  In biliary colic, there is no associated fever, leukocytosis, or concerning changes on ultrasonography (eg, gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid), as would be seen in acute cholecystitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis:  Both conditions present with RUQ and epigastric pain, but pancreatitis often involves radiating pain directly to the back and elevated serum lipase/amylase levels.  Amylase and lipase levels should be normal in acute cholecystitis.
  • Acute cholangitis:  Although both conditions have RUQ pain and fever, acute cholangitis (ascending infection of the biliary tree) also presents with jaundice, demonstrating Charcot triad: fever, jaundice, and RUQ pain.  Reynolds pentad (Charcot triad plus hypotension and altered mental status) can be seen in severe cases.
  • Acute hepatitis:  Acute hepatitis often presents similarly to gallstone disease with RUQ pain.  On laboratory evaluation, however, acute hepatitis has diffuse hepatocellular injury with marked transaminase elevation (aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase), which would not be expected in acute cholecystitis.
  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD):  Epigastric pain caused by PUD can mimic acute cholecystitis.  However, pain related to ulcers may improve with food (eg, depending on the location of the ulcer).  Pain from acute cholecystitis typically worsens with the ingestion of food and subsequent gallbladder contraction.
  • Acute myocardial infarction (MI):  Epigastric pain and nausea can mimic gallstone disease, particularly in women or patients with diabetes mellitus whose condition may present more atypically.  MI, however, is associated with ECG changes and cardiac enzyme elevations.  Physical examination in MI should not elicit tenderness in the RUQ.

Management



The treatment of acute cholecystitis typically involves supportive care, antibiotics, and surgical intervention.

Initial management



  • NPO status:  Patients should be kept NPO to reduce gallbladder stimulation and to prepare for surgical management.
  • Intravenous fluids:  Adequate hydration is necessary to prevent hypovolemia and maintain hemodynamic stability.
  • Analgesia:  Intravenous pain medications such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or opioids can be used for pain control.
  • Antibiotics:  Broad-spectrum antibiotics are recommended to cover common gut flora such as E coli, Klebsiella, and Enterococcus.  Agents such as piperacillin-tazobactam or a combination of ceftriaxone and metronidazole are commonly used.

Definitive treatment



  • Cholecystectomy:  Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for acute cholecystitis and is typically performed within 72 hours of symptom onset.  Delay to surgical intervention increases the risk for complications such as perforation.
  • Percutaneous cholecystostomy:  For patients who are poor surgical candidates due to comorbidities or critical illness, percutaneous cholecystostomy (drainage of the gallbladder via catheter placed in the abdominal wall) may be performed as a temporizing measure (
    figure 3
    ).

Complications



  • Gangrenous cholecystitis:  Prolonged ischemia of the gallbladder wall due to venous congestion and edema can result in necrosis.  This increases the risk for perforation of the gallbladder wall, which can result in generalized peritonitis or abscess formation.
  • Gallbladder empyema:  Gallbladder empyema is characterized by the collection of infected purulent material mixed with bile in the lumen of the gallbladder.  The purulent bilious material can rapidly fill the gallbladder, increasing pressure on its wall and propagating ischemia and gangrene.
  • Emphysematous cholecystitis:  Caused by gas-forming organisms (such as Clostridium), this rare and life-threatening form of cholecystitis occurs more frequently in patients with diabetes mellitus.  On CT imaging, there is evidence of air within the gallbladder wall or air-fluid levels within the gallbladder lumen (
    figure 4
    ).
  • Sepsis:  Bacterial translocation from the infected gallbladder into the bloodstream can lead to sepsis and bacteremia.  Immunocompromised patients, the elderly, and those with comorbid conditions are at higher risk.

Prognosis



The prognosis for acute calculous cholecystitis is generally favorable with timely diagnosis and appropriate management.  Most patients recover fully after cholecystectomy.  However, delayed treatment can lead to complications such as perforation and sepsis; death can also occur.  Acalculous cholecystitis carries a higher risk for mortality due to its association with critical illness.

Summary



Acute cholecystitis is an inflammatory condition of the gallbladder most commonly caused by gallstone obstruction of the cystic duct (ie, acute calculous cholecystitis).  When this condition occurs in the absence of a gallstone, it is called "acute acalculous cholecystitis."  Imaging studies, particularly right upper quadrant ultrasonography, play a crucial role in making the diagnosis.  The differential diagnosis is broad, but clinical examination and laboratory/imaging studies can be used to identify the correct condition.  Early recognition and treatment, including supportive care, antibiotics, and cholecystectomy, are essential to preventing serious complications.  For severely ill patients, percutaneous cholecystostomy may be used as a bridge to delayed cholecystectomy.  The prognosis is excellent with timely surgical intervention, although the condition can be life-threatening if treatment is delayed or complications occur.
